course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Introductory Biological Physics
course.description: This course introduces the use of physical methods in the study of biological systems, including macromolecules, membranes, nerves, muscle, photosynthetic systems and visual systems. The biological systems to which the methods are applied will be surveyed and current interpretations of their structure and function will be discussed. The treatment of biological phenomena will be based on physical principles with appropriate mathematics when necessary. The emphasis will be on the applications of physics in biology.
course.prerequisites: (LIFS 1901 OR level 3 or above in HKDSE 1xBiology) AND (PHYS 1111 OR PHYS 1112 OR PHYS 1312)

reviews.author: _NattU_
reviews.comment_content:
This course's previous code was BIPH2010. Topics include:

1) Life from the Perspective of Physics
2) Whatâ€™s Inside Cells: The Structure of Biological Molecules
3) The Structure of Biological Molecules
4) Molecular Driving Forces: Statistical Thermodynamics
5) Statistical Thermodynamics of Life
6) Biological Polymers.
7) Diffusion
8) Life at Low Reynolds Number
9) Rate Equations and Dynamics in the Cell
10) Molecular Motor
11) Physical Properties of Cell Membrane
12) Physics of neuron

The content might be slightly complicated at times for students without an adequate physics and biology background. However, the course assessments are quite easy and do not test our more advanced topics.

Ref textbook: Physical Biology of the Cell by Rob Phillips
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Park is the NICEST professor you can find in UST. He's passionate, and caring, and answers any questions you have. His english/presentation skills may be slightly polarizing among the student body but he puts in the effort. More importantly, he ensures good grades to his students and always arranges generous bonuses to boost our grades. He assured that most students will score at least B+.
reviews.comment_grading:
Course Assessment Scheme:

HW: 30%
Midterm: 30%
Final: 40%
Bonus project report: 15%

The bonus project is a 3-5 page report about the application of biological physics in our daily life or some important question in biology physics (e.g. Fluid Dynamics of Blood Flow, Quantum Mechanics in Enzyme Kinetics). The weight of the report might be changed depending on the class performance.

The exams are closed-book but all the necessary formulae and constants are given in the exam paper.

My scores:
HW: 399/425   (mean: 301)
Midterm: 24/30 (mean: 18)
Finals scores are undisclosed. However, I'm pretty sure I scored 35+ out of 40.
Bonus report scores also weren't released.

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
One HW every week (~1-3 questions). Relatively easy as long as you are able to understand what formula is applicable for the problem at hand. Tutorials always give out hints for HW before the deadline.

Exams are relatively easy as long as you are good at calculations with a good sense of problem-solving. Prof gives many hints on what kinds of problems will appear in the exam during his lectures.

The bonus project report might take some effort though as you need to explore literature and come up with a concrete project that displays your understanding of the subject matter in a logical manner.Of course, don't copy from ChatGPT, prof runs an AI checker.
